intro: Tryphostemma pedatum, commonly known as the creeping yellowwood, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family, which includes coffee and gardenias, and is characterized by its slender, trailing stems. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers that are clustered in umbels, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, simple, and have a slightly hairy texture, often with a bluish-green hue. Tryphostemma pedatum thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas.
